qas.question: What is the term given to students who lived in town, but not on the campus of Eton?
Oppidan residences were generally cared after by women known as what?

answers.text: the teacher who lives in the house and manages the pupils in it

qas.question: About how many students are in a typical Oppidan house?
What is the term for boys who live on Eton's campus?
What is one of the House's names?
Where do boys on Eton's campus live?
What is the Latin term for "school"?

context: As the School grew, more students were allowed to attend provided that they paid their own fees and lived in the town, outside the College's original buildings. These students became known as <a0_0><b4_0><b6_0>Oppidans<b6_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>, from the Latin word <b8_0>oppidum<b8_0/>, meaning town. The <b7_0>Houses<b7_0/> developed over time as a means of providing residence for the Oppidans in a more congenial manner, and during the <b5_0>18<b5_0/>th and 19th centuries were mostly run by women known as <a1_0>"dames"<a1_0/>. They typically contain about <a3_0>fifty<a3_0/> boys. Although classes are organised on a School basis, most boys spend a large proportion of their time in their House. Each House has a formal name, mainly used for post and people outside the Eton community. It is generally known by the boys by the initials or surname of the House Master, <a2_0>the teacher who lives in the house and manages the pupils in it<a2_0/>.
